title: [$250] Fix IndexedDB transaction memory leak in multiMerge

labels.name: External
labels.description: Added to denote the issue can be worked on by a contributor

labels.name: Bug
labels.description: Something is broken. Auto assigns a BugZero manager.

body:
Coming from slack [here](https://expensify.slack.com/archives/C05LX9D6E07/p1760106050038389) Proposal: Fix IndexedDB transaction memory leak in multiMerge ### Background: Onyx uses IndexedDB (via idb-keyval) as the storage layer on web. The multiMerge operation is one of the most frequently called storage operations, executing thousands of times during app initialization for accounts with substantial data. Currently, multiMerge uses a manual transaction pattern where it directly accesses the IDBObjectStore via idbKeyValStore('readwrite', (store) => {...}) to perform read-then-write operations within a single transaction. This pattern creates a transaction object that remains in memory along with all its associated IDBRequest objects and promise chains. For heavy accounts in Expensify, a single page load can trigger thousands of multiMerge calls, each creating these transaction structures. ### Problem: When users with heavy accounts load the app, if Onyx performs thousands of multiMerge operations, then the manual transaction pattern retains 383MB+ of memory in IDBDatabase and IDBTransaction objects that are never garbage collected, causing the app to crash or become unresponsive. ### Solution: Fix the multiMerge implementation to eliminate manual transaction management and let idb-keyval handle transaction lifecycle automatically ends. The specific code change is moving the .then(() => undefined) outside the idbKeyValStore callback so the transaction can complete immediately after all put operations finish, rather than being kept alive by the outer promise chain. Impact: Memory snapshots show this reduces the retained size from 383,727KB (36% of total heap) down to ~1,000KB (negligible). This also prevents the accumulation of 100,000+ IDBTransaction objects in memory. Draf PR: https://github.com/Expensify/react-native-onyx/pull/688

title: [$250] Calculate footer sub-totals in `Explore` sections on `Reports` when specific expenses are selected

labels.name: External
labels.description: Added to denote the issue can be worked on by a contributor

labels.name: NewFeature
labels.description: Something to build that is a new item.

labels.name: Help Wanted
labels.description: Apply this label when an issue is open to proposals by contributors

body:
At the moment we calculate footer sub-totals on the `Reports` page for all LHN sections with the exception of `Explore`. We adopted this approach for two reasons: 1) The data is unbounded and so querying it involves performance considerations; 2) A total of everything from all time has questionable utility. That said, when any expenses or reports are selected in `Explore` > `Expenses` or `Explore` > `Reports`, we would like to start counting footer totals, so number of expenses/reports and total value. I believe this update should be pretty straightforward, no matter if we're dealing with different currencies, using all the existing logic we already have, though let us know if you have any questions! cc @luacmartins

body:
If you haven’t already, check out our [contributing guidelines](https://github.com/Expensify/ReactNativeChat/blob/main/contributingGuides/CONTRIBUTING.md) for onboarding and email contributors@expensify.com to request to join our Slack channel! ___ **Version Number:** **Reproducible in staging?:** Needs Reproduction **Reproducible in production?:** Needs Reproduction **If this was caught during regression testing, add the test name, ID and link from TestRail:** **Email or phone of affected tester (no customers):** **Logs:** https://stackoverflow.com/c/expensify/questions/4856 **Expensify/Expensify Issue URL:** **Issue reported by:** @NicMendonca **Slack conversation** (hyperlinked to channel name): [#Convert](https://expensify.slack.com/archives/C07HPDRELLD/p1759931592044839) ## Action Performed: 1. As an approver, receive an email for a report pending your approval 2. Open the link or navigation path provided to view reports awaiting action 3. Observe which filter is applied when the reports page loads ## Expected Result: The user should be directed to the “Approve” filter, showing reports that require their approval. ## Actual Result: The user is incorrectly directed to the “Pay” filter, which shows reports awaiting payment instead of approval. ## Workaround: Unknown ## Platforms: Select the officially supported platforms where the issue was reproduced: - [ ] Android: App - [ ] Android: mWeb Chrome - [ ] iOS: App - [ ] iOS: mWeb Safari - [ ] iOS: mWeb Chrome - [x] Windows: Chrome - [x] MacOS: Chrome / Safari - [ ] MacOS: Desktop
Platforms Tested: On which of our officially supported platforms was this issue tested: - [ ] Android: App - [ ] Android: mWeb Chrome - [ ] iOS: App - [ ] iOS: mWeb Safari - [ ] iOS: mWeb Chrome - [ ] Windows: Chrome - [ ] MacOS: Chrome / Safari - [ ] MacOS: Desktop
